sn11.9:4.2: “Once upon a time, mendicants, several seers who were ethical, of good character, settled in leaf huts in a wilderness region.
sn11.9:4.3: Then Sakka, Lord of Gods, and Vepacitti, Lord of Demons, went to those seers.
sn11.9:4.4: Then Vepacitti put on his boots, strapped on his sword, and, carrying a sunshade, entered the hermitage through the main gate. He walked right past those seers, keeping them at a distance.
sn11.9:4.5: Then Sakka took off his boots, gave his sword to others, and, putting down his sunshade, entered the hermitage through a gate he happened upon. He stood downwind of those seers, revering them with cupped palms.
sn11.9:4.6: Then those seers addressed Sakka in verse:
sn11.9:5.2: the odor of their bodies goes with the wind.
sn11.9:5.4: The odor of the seers is unclean, king of gods.’
sn11.9:6.2: let the odor of their bodies go with the wind.
sn11.9:6.3: We yearn for this odor, sirs,
sn11.9:6.4: like a colorful crown of flowers.
sn11.9:6.5: The gods don’t see it as repulsive.’”
